comments:
build M20021023 (2.0.2 candidate build)

- installed M20021023
- ran it, pointing at my existing 2.1 workspace
- it came up with no warnings, and showed the structure of the workspace OK, 
but none of the editors were restored (may not actually be a problem
- the log had the following
- since the environment came up OK, it looks to me as if this error was simply 
logged when it couldn't read the markers, but if so, why bother logging it?

The alternative is not to tell the user anything and to have markers not appear 
in the workspace and no information as to why in the log file.

Do we really want to go this route?

Note there are multiple other areas in the SDK where we silently ignore 
problems but log them to the file.

For me as a developer seeing the stack trace, the main confusion was wondering 
whether it had been able to continue or not.  It would help to know the bounds 
of the failure.  E.g. "Error reading markers.  Continuing to restore rest of 
workspace.".

Original title: 
[resources] IOException reading 2.1 workspace in 2.0.

Investigate to see if we can better present this information to the user and 
let them know that things aren't completely hosed if they get this error. 

Code is in or around SaveManager.restoreMarkers.

This is a servicability issue.

Workspace restore categorizes problems into:

1) Catastrophic failure
2) Minor failures

In the case of 1), we have decided that restoring the workspace is impossible
(some critical file is corrupt).  In this case we throw an exception and the
workbench will not start.

In the case of 2), we log the message above. So, if you see this message, it
means the workspace was restored, but some part of it was not (such as markers
or sync info).  I have changed the error message to be less scary.  It now says:

"Workspace restored, but some problems occurred."
